. This taxonomy is used in the catRef encoding to classify the testimonia according to the time period(s) of the events described, rather than the date of composition of the testimonium. For example, Josephus may describe events occuring well before the period of his writing.

profileDesc.creation: This entry is taken from Ecclesiastical History 6.23 written by Eusebius of Caesarea in 312 - 324 CE. This work was likely written in Caesarea.

body.desc: Caesarea, are place names attested in Eusebius of Caesarea's Ecclesiastical History 6.23. This testimonium was written circa 312 - 324 CE. This work was likely written in Caesarea.

Starting from that time also Origen‚Äôs commentaries on the divine Scriptures had their beginning, at the instigation of Ambrose, who not only plied him with innumerable verbal exhortations and encouragements, but also provided him unstintingly with what was necessary. For as he dictated there were ready at hand more than seven shorthand-writers, who relieved each other at fixed times, and as many copyists, as well as girls skilled in penmanship; for all of them Ambrose supplied without stint the necessary means. Furthermore he contributed to Origen a vast amount of zeal in the earnest study of the divine oracles, a zeal which more than anything else acted as an incentive to him to compose his commentarieses. Such was the state of affairs when Pontianus succeeded Urbanus, who had been bishop of the Church of the Romans for eight years, and Zebennus came after Philetus as [bishop] of the [Church] of the Antiochenes. In their day Origen journeyed to Greece through Palestine because of an urgent necessity in Church matters, and received the laying-on of hands for the presbyterate at Caesarea from the bishops there.
